thread.title: Coinbase Enhanced Security Measures Scam

author: Tomas Meskauskas
title: Coinbase Enhanced Security Measures Scam
text:
How to spot scams like "Coinbase Enhanced Security Measures" fake website
[ Written by ](https://www.pcrisk.com/tomas-meskauskas)[Tomas Meskauskas](https://www.pcrisk.com/tomas-meskauskas) on
What is "Coinbase Enhanced Security Measures"?
Our team has examined this website and found that it mimics the real page (coinbase.com) to trick individuals into taking actions that could result in significant financial losses. This fraudulent platform should be avoided. It is advisable to always verify the legitimacy of web pages before interacting with them.
IMPORTANT NOTE: We do not review crypto projects, please do your own research when investing money.
[Federal Trade Comission (FTC) states](https://www.ftc.gov/news-events/data-visualizations/data-spotlight/2022/06/reports-show-scammers-cashing-crypto-craze) that since the start of 2021, more than 46,000 people have reported losing over $1 billion in crypto to scams – that's about one out of every four dollars reported lost, more than any other payment method.
"Coinbase Enhanced Security Measures" scam in detail
Coinbase (coinbase.com) is a popular cryptocurrency exchange platform that allows users to buy, sell, trade, and store various cryptocurrencies, such as Bitcoin, Ethereum, and others. It is a legitimate platform and should not be confused with the fraudulent one (web3walletbase[.]com).
On the fake website, users are informed that their account requires additional verification to protect their assets. The site encourages users to connect their wallets and confirm access rights to complete the security check. Connecting a wallet on this fake website activates a cryptocurrency drainer.
This drainer is a malicious tool designed to transfer cryptocurrency from the victim's wallet to the scammer's. In other words, it allows scammers to steal cryptocurrency from victims. Unfortunately, recovering stolen cryptocurrency is extremely difficult because crypto transactions are irreversible.
Once funds are sent to a scammer's wallet, they cannot be retrieved unless the scammer willingly returns them. Therefore, it is important to be careful when connecting wallets, providing personal information, or making transactions. Before performing these actions, users should always ensure the platform they use is legitimate.
Name | Coinbase Enhanced Security Measures fraudulent site |
Threat Type | Phishing, Scam, Social Engineering, Fraud |
Fake Claim | Coinbase account requires additional verification to protect assets |
Disguise | Official Coinbase platform |
Related Domain | web3walletbase[.]com |
Detection Names (web3walletbase[.]com) | CRDF (Malicious), Fortinet (Phishing), Kaspersky (Phishing), Sophos (Malware), VIPRE (Malware), Full List Of Detections (
|

Similar scams in general
Scam websites involving cryptocurrency drainers are crafted to look legitimate, often imitating trusted platforms to deceive users. They usually instruct potential victims to connect their wallets to get free tokens. However, they sometimes use tactics involving fake alerts regarding account security to lure individuals.
Examples of similar scams are the fake "[Binance Bitcoin Payout](/removal-guides/31561-binance-bitcoin-payout-scam)", "[$PAW Token Exchange](/removal-guides/31523-paw-token-exchange-scam)", and "[LINGO Airdrop](/removal-guides/31520-lingo-airdrop-scam)" platforms.
How did I open a scam website?
Scam sites involving crypto drainers are commonly spread through hijacked WordPress sites or hacked (or fake) social media accounts (e.g., X/Twitter, Facebook, and other platforms). Visiting sites connected to rogue ad networks often found on torrent sites, illegal streaming services, or adult websites, can also direct users to fraudulent pages.
In other cases, users can open scam websites via unreliable ads, pop-ups, misleading buttons, suspicious links, and deceptive emails. Adware can also redirect users to these harmful sites. Overall, scammers use various methods to lure users into visiting scam websites.
How to avoid visiting scam pages?
Be careful with emails or messages from unknown sources, especially if they have links or attachments. Do not click on pop-ups, ads, and other content on suspicious sites, and avoid torrent sites, illegal streaming pages, and similar platforms. Avoid allowing shady sites to send you notifications.
Make sure to scan your computer regularly with trusted security software and keep everything (including the operating system) up to date. Only download software from official websites or app stores. If your computer is already infected with unwanted apps, we recommend running a scan with [Combo Cleaner Antivirus for Windows](/download-combo-cleaner-windows) to automatically eliminate them.

Quick menu:
[What is Coinbase Enhanced Security Measures fraudulent site?](#a1)[How to identify a pop-up scam?](#how-to-identify-a-pop-up-scam)[How do pop-up scams work?](#how-do-pop-up-scams-work)[How to remove fake pop-ups?](#how-to-remove-fake-pop-ups)[How to prevent fake pop-ups?](#prevention)[What to do if you fell for a pop-up scam?](#what-to-do-if-you-fell-for-a-pop-up-scam)
How to identify a pop-up scam?
Pop-up windows with various fake messages are a common type of lures cybercriminals use. They collect sensitive personal data, trick Internet users into calling fake tech support numbers, subscribe to useless online services, invest in shady cryptocurrency schemes, etc.
While in the majority of cases these pop-ups don't infect users' devices with malware, they can cause direct monetary loss or could result in identity theft.
Cybercriminals strive to create their rogue pop-up windows to look trustworthy, however, scams typically have the following characteristics:
- Spelling mistakes and non-professional images - Closely inspect the information displayed in a pop-up. Spelling mistakes and unprofessional images could be a sign of a scam.
- Sense of urgency - Countdown timer with a couple of minutes on it, asking you to enter your personal information or subscribe to some online service.
- Statements that you won something - If you haven't participated in a lottery, online competition, etc., and you see a pop-up window stating that you won.
- Computer or mobile device scan - A pop-up window that scans your device and informs of detected issues - is undoubtedly a scam; webpages cannot perform such actions.
- Exclusivity - Pop-up windows stating that only you are given secret access to a financial scheme that can quickly make you rich.
Example of a pop-up scam:
How do pop-up scams work?
Cybercriminals and deceptive marketers usually use various advertising networks, search engine poisoning techniques, and shady websites to generate traffic to their pop-ups. Users land on their online lures after clicking on fake download buttons, using a torrent website, or simply clicking on an Internet search engine result.
Based on users' location and device information, they are presented with a scam pop-up. Lures presented in such pop-ups range from get-rich-quick schemes to fake virus scans.
How to remove fake pop-ups?
In most cases, pop-up scams do not infect users' devices with malware. If you encountered a scam pop-up, simply closing it should be enough. In some cases scam, pop-ups may be hard to close; in such cases - close your Internet browser and restart it.
In extremely rare cases, you might need to reset your Internet browser. For this, use our instructions explaining [how to reset Internet browser settings](/how-to-remove-spyware/reset-browser-settings).
How to prevent fake pop-ups?
To prevent seeing pop-up scams, you should visit only reputable websites. Torrent, Crack, free online movie streaming, YouTube video download, and other websites of similar reputation commonly redirect Internet users to pop-up scams.
To minimize the risk of encountering pop-up scams, you should keep your Internet browsers up-to-date and use reputable anti-malware application. For this purpose, we recommend [Combo Cleaner Antivirus for Windows](/download-combo-cleaner-windows).
What to do if you fell for a pop-up scam?
This depends on the type of scam that you fell for. Most commonly, pop-up scams try to trick users into sending money, giving away personal information, or giving access to one's device.
- If you sent money to scammers: You should contact your financial institution and explain that you were scammed. If informed promptly, there's a chance to get your money back.
- If you gave away your personal information: You should change your passwords and enable two-factor authentication in all online services that you use. Visit
[Federal Trade Commission](https://www.identitytheft.gov)to report identity theft and get personalized recovery steps. - If you let scammers connect to your device: You should scan your computer with reputable anti-malware (we recommend
[Combo Cleaner Antivirus for Windows](/download-combo-cleaner-windows)) - cyber criminals could have planted trojans, keyloggers, and other malware, don't use your computer until removing possible threats. - Help other Internet users: report Internet scams to
[Federal Trade Commission](https://reportfraud.ftc.gov).
Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ)
What is a scam website?
A scam website, often designed to appear legitimate, is a deceptive site created to mislead users. Scammers use such pages to trick individuals into actions that can result in financial loss, identity theft, or other issues.
What is the purpose of a scam website?
Fraudsters can utilize it to steal money, including cryptocurrency, sensitive information like credit card details and passwords, or to distribute malicious software.
Why do I encounter scam websites?
Scam sites are spread through hacked websites, fake social media accounts, and rogue advertising networks (often used by torrent, illegal movie streaming, and similar sites). Users can also be directed to these fraudulent pages via misleading links, pop-ups, ads, and deceptive emails.
Will Combo Cleaner protect me from scam websites?
Combo Cleaner scans websites for risks, detects malicious sites (including scam websites), and notifies users. It also blocks access to scam sites and other harmful pages.
